description: Luxemburg is restricting social movement to essential acitivities, including grocery shopping, essential travel to work, way to hospital, in order to visit people in need, in an emergency situation and in order to exercise (with 2 meters distance).

Luxemburg is declaring a state of crisis on 17 March, which gives the Government the possibility to set up emergency measures in order to face the crisis. Thus, a regulatory and legal framework is established, in line with the Luxembourg Constitution: the scope covered by this Article is limited to measures which cannot be taken in good time through the normal legislative procedure. The Chamber of Deputies can, at every moment, suspend or revoke the state of crisis: Parliamentary control is this fully guaranteed.

Luxemburg banned third-country nationals to enter the territory of the Grand Duchy. The restriction was put in place, initially, for a one month period starting on March 18, 2020.  There are several exemptions from this ban, including for  Belgian, French, and German cross-border workers.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: German frontier workers are excempt from the Luxemburg entry ban. The Luxembourg government has issued a certificate the worker needs to carry with them, as proof of the need to cross the border. 18 March.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: French frontier workers are excempt from the Luxemburg entry ban. The Luxembourg government has issued a certificate the worker needs to carry with them, as proof of the need to cross the border together with the attestation of necessary travel and the justification of necessary travel.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Belgian frontier workers ar exempted from the entry ban in Luxemburg, the Luxembourg government has issued a certificate the worker needs to carry with them, as proof of the need to cross the border. 18 March.

description: Luxemburg: Since 15 June, there have been no more controls at Luxembourg's borders with the 3 border countries.
Luxemburg is opening three specified medical centres for patients with coronavirus symptoms on 18. March.

Luxemburg bans all stationary visits in hospitals, all essential vitis need to be processed with higthened health security measures. Planned hospital acitivies are recommended to be canceled and staff is recommended to cancel leave.
Luxembourg: As of 4 May, hospitals are very gradually resuming their medical, surgical and care activities, based on the priority needs of patients
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government

description: Luxembourg: As of 4 May, hospitals are very gradually resuming their medical, surgical and care activities, based on the priority needs of patients.

description: 20.6. Luxembourg wants to prevent a second wave of corona with comprehensive tests of the entire population.

Luxemburg announces that from 24 March onwards the RGTR bus lines 158 Kirchberg - Remich - Merzig (D) and 159 Luxembourg - Losheim (D) will be diverted via Schengen, then Besch, to Nennig. From then on the routes remain unchanged. Nennig Zoll is replaced by Nennig Bahnhof.
target_geog_level: A geographical or administrative unit within a country
target_city: 58 Kirchberg – Remich – Merzig (D) und 159 Luxemburg – Losheim (D),Schengen, dann Besch, nach Nennig

description: Luxembourg: Retirement and nursing homes - family visits no longer prohibited, sanitary restrictions stay in place
type_sub_cat: Lockdown only applies to people of certain ages (Please note the age restriction in the text box)

description: Luxemburg is recommending risk groups to reduce social interaction, travel and avoiding mass gatherings and hospital visits.
type_text: The Luxemburg government has issued official recommendations for risk groups to avoid travel, social gatherings, shopping at rush hours and public transport.

description: Luxemburg is recommending a visitors ban on care homes to all relatives and friends of residents of elderly homes.
type_text: Luxemburg recommended to implement a visitors ban in all elderly homes.

description: Luxembourg: Covid-19: Introduction of family support leave
type_text: As part of the government's measures to limit the spread of coronavirus, paid leave was introduced to support the family. This leave is intended to help private sector workers and self-employed persons who are forced to stop working due to the closure of an institution for people with a disability or for elderly people, so that they can care for an adult with a disability or for an elderly person living in their household.

description: Luxembourg: COVID-19: New procedure for applying for short-time work in cases of force majeure due to the COVID-19 crisis announced on March 27.
type_text: In order to preserve jobs and thus prevent redundancies, Luxembourg labour law provides for various regulations on short-time working. Short-time work enables companies to keep well-trained and experienced employees in employment even in times of crisis.
The Policy sets out repayable financial aid to compensate for temporary financial difficulties caused by the COVID-19 crisis in Luxembourg
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Luxembourg: Partial unemployment extended until end of 2020
type_text: The government and unions have reached an agreement to support businesses through partial unemployment.
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: The Luxemburg Ministry of Health is starting a public health awareness campaigns surrounding COVID-19 on 29.92.2020.

description: Luxemburg is restricting non-essential business from 16 March onwards with the expection of grocery stores, pharmacies, other kinds of food shops and opptricians, pet food shops, telecom shops, fuel stations, shops for health equipment, night shops, kiosks.
Luxembourg's objective is to implement a gradual exit from confinement in phases while remaining cautious. Construction sites resumed their activities from 20 April  2020.
